Comparative study of gas-phase “dehydration” of alkyl lactates and lactic acid for acrylic acid production over hydroxyapatite catalysts Zong-Hui Liu Investigation Resources Writing - original draft Bo Yan Supervision Resources Validation Writing - review & editing Yu Liang Supervision Methodology Validation Bo-Qing Xu Conceptualization Data curation Formal analysis Funding acquisition Methodology Project administration Resources Supervision Visualization Writing - review & editing * Innovative Catalysis Program, Key Lab of Organic Optoelectronics & Molecular Engineering, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China Innovative Catalysis Program Key Lab of Organic Optoelectronics & Molecular Engineering Department of Chemistry Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China Innovative Catalysis Program, Key Lab of Organic Optoelectronics & Molecular Engineering, Department of Chemistry, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Gas-phase “dehydration” of methyl (ML) and ethyl lactates (EL) for acrylic acid (AA) production was studied and compared with the dehydration of lactic acid (LA) over serial hydroxyapatite catalysts of varying compositions (HAP m -360, molar Ca/P ratio m = 1.58–1.68, calcination temperature: 360 °C). The product distribution from both lactic esters was found very similar to that from LA; AA but not methyl (MA) or ethyl acrylate (EA) also appeared as the prevailing product (> 50 mol% by selectivity) from both ML and EL. Compared with the reaction of LA, both esters showed much lower reactivity but higher AA selectivity. Among the two esters EL was less reactive but produced a higher selectivity for AA formation. Correlating the AA selectivity or yield with the catalyst surface acid-base property uncovers that a suitable balance between the surface acidity and basicity (or acidity/basicity ratio) is the key to the lactic ester-to-AA reactions. However, the optimum surface acidity/basicity ratio for producing the highest AA selectivity from both esters was higher than that from LA. These results suggest that the lactic ester-to-AA reactions proceeded by catalytic tandem processes involving a formation of LA (or adsorbed lactate) as the key intermediate at the catalyst surface. Acid-base catalysis responsible for these observations is discussed. Keywords Acrylic acid production Catalytic dehydration Hydroxyapatite Acid-base catalysis Sustainable chemistry 1 Introduction Acrylic acid (AA) is known as a versatile monomer for many kinds of polymers that are widely used in super absorbents, detergents, dispersants, thickeners and textiles [1,2]. The current industrial technology of AA production is based on selective catalytic oxidation of petroleum-derived propylene or propane [3,4]. Recently, AA production by catalytic conversion of lactic acid (LA) [5–23] and its esters, like methyl and ethyl lactates (ML and EL) [24–33], has been proposed as a green and sustainable alternative to the current technology. LA and its esters could be inexpensively obtained through fermentation of various biomass resources (carbohydrates), which have been recommended as one category of the most promising platform molecules to meet the future for renewable fuels and chemicals [34–37]. The production of AA by catalytic dehydration of LA (or LTA reaction) is made possible by selective activation of the α-hydroxyl and β-hydrogen in LA with acid-base bifunctional catalysts including modified zeolites [5–14], sulfates [15–17], phosphates [18–20] and hydroxyapatites [21–23]. Due to the unavoidable high reactivity of the hydroxyl and carboxylic groups, the LTA reaction is always accompanied by competing reactions, including decarbonylation/decarboxylation to acetaldehyde (AD) [38–40], bimolecular condensation to 2,3-pentanedione (2,3-PD) [41–43], hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis to propionic acid (PA) and intermolecular esterification to lactide [20,22,23]. In comparison to LA, the alkyl lactates (or lactic esters) would be less reactive and their ester function could greatly lessen the competiveness of the undesirable decarbonylation/decarboxylation, intermolecular esterification and condensation reactions. The industrial grade raw LA from biomass fermentation is usually purified by esterification with methanol or ethanol to form the lactic esters, followed by hydrolysis of the esters to obtain high purity LA [34,44]. Furthermore, lactic esters are less corrosive than LA and new processes that making the esters directly from sugars are being developed [45–53]. It would thus be economically more attractive if the lactic esters, ML [24–31] and EL [32,33], could be directly employed for AA production by identifying appropriate solid catalysts. While there is rich literature dealing with performance of various solid acid-base catalysts for the LTA reaction [5–23], reports on AA production from the lactic esters especially EL are surprisingly less [27,32,33]. Also, it is difficult to make a comparison between the reactions of LA, ML and EL using the data documented in literature from different laboratories because such data were mostly generated over different catalysts and moreover under very diverse reaction conditions (temperature, reaction feed composition and space velocity, reaction time-on-stream and etc.). The motivation of this work is to compare the relative reactivity of LA, ML and EL and highlight the feature of using ML and/or EL for AA production by conducting the reactions under otherwise identical conditions over the same catalysts. A previous work from this laboratory showed that a properly prepared hydroxyapatite solid with a suitable composition (HAP m -T, m and T refer to the molar Ca/P ratio and calcination temperature in degree Celsius, respectively), like HAP1.62-360, can be an efficient catalyst for LTA [23]. By manipulation of m and T to adjust the surface acid − base property of the HAP m -T catalyst, we demonstrated that cooperative acid-base catalysis was responsible for the selective AA production from LA and a balance between the catalyst surface acidity and basicity was the key to the catalyst performance [23]. In this work, the same serial HAP m -360 catalysts (HAP m -T samples of T =360 °C), which produced among different HAP m -T samples the highest AA yield in that prior work [23], are employed to compare the reactions of ML, EL and LA and to understand the similarity/dissimilarity for AA productions from the reactions of aqueous ML, EL and LA. We confirm that suitably balanced acidity and basicity at the surface of HAP catalysts is also the key for AA production from either of the ester reactants. Also, the use of ML or EL instead of LA as the reactant always offers a higher AA selectivity though LA shows a higher reactivity. Careful comparison of the product distribution from both esters and LA points to that the chemistry of AA production from either ester involves two consecutive processes at the catalyst surface; a slow ester (ML or EL) hydrolysis process producing alcohol (methanol or ethanol) and LA or surface lactate as the intermediate, followed by a fast dehydration of the intermediate to produce AA. This catalytic tandem chemistry is corroborated by the observation of a significantly higher catalytic rate and lower apparent energy barrier for the reaction of LA than of EL. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The HAP m -360 samples with varying m (molar Ca/P ratio) were prepared by adjusting the molar ratio of Ca(NO3)2 and (NH4)2HPO4, as reported previously [23]. Typically, 250 mL of aqueous (NH4)2HPO4 (0.25 mol/L) was added dropwise under stirring into the desired amount of aqueous of Ca(NO3)2 (250 mL) at pH = 10.0. The resultant suspensions were aged at 40 °C for 12 h before the product precipitates were separated by filtration. The precipitates were washed with deionized water until conductivity of the filtrate was less than 10 μS cm−1, then dried overnight at 110 °C, and finally calcined for 5 h at 360 °C in flowing air to give the HAPm-360 samples. The number m (or Ca/P) of HAP m -360 samples were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) on a Shimadzu XRF-1800 fluorescence spectrometer coupled with Rh radiation at 40 kV and 70 mA. The BET surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter data were derived from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010C instrument [23]. Surface acidic and basic properties were evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) conducted on a Cat-Lab instrument (BEL, Japan) equipped with a well-calibrated quadrupole mass spectrometer (Inprocess Instruments, GAM 200) as the detector [10−12]. The amount of surface carbonaceous deposits on the reacted catalysts were measured by Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) in flowing dry air in thermal gravimetric analysis (TG) mode on a Mettler-Toledo TG/SDTA 851 thermal analyzer [10,12,23]. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The catalytic reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor (50 cm ×9 mm (i.d.)), mounted in a cylindrical electrical furnace under atmospheric pressure at 360 °C, as reported previously in our earlier studies of the LTA reaction [10–12,23]. In a typical experiment, 500 mg of catalyst (20–40 mesh) was sandwiched in the middle section of the reactor with quartz wools. A quartz sands bed (ca. 2 mL) was placed above the catalyst bed for preheating and completely vaporizing the liquid feed. Before the start of the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated at the reaction temperature for 1 h in flowing high-purity N2 (25 mLmin−1). A 10 mol% aqueous solution of LA, EL or ML was introduced into the reactor with N2 as the reaction carrier gas. The effluents from the reactor were condensed with an ice-water trap and collected hourly for analyses by both GC (Agilent GC, HP7890A) equipped with an SGE BP20 capillary column (0.32 mm ×25 m) and a flame ionization detector (FID), and ion chromatograph (Metrohm Ion Chromatography, 883) equipped with a Metrosep A supp4 column and a conductivity detector; details for the GC (gas chromatography) and IC (ionic chromatography) analyses were documented previously [23]. Material balances of the reactions were always higher than 95 % except in the very first hour. The conversion of the reactant, product selectivity, and AA yield were obtained according to the following calculations: Reactant conversion % = moles of reactant consumed moles of reactant in the feed × 100 Product selectivity ( C % ) = moles of carbon atoms in the product defined 3 × moles of reactant consumed × 100 AA yield C % = moles of AA produced moles of reactant in the feed × 100 The calculation of the product selectivity by carbon balance did not include the methyl or ethyl group when the reaction feed was aqueous ML or EL, unless the product was methyl or ethyl acrylate. This is acceptable as the methyl groups appeared quantitatively in methanol and methyl acrylate during the reaction of ML, and the ethyl in ethanol and ethyl acrylate during the reaction of EL. Also, no reaction was detected when aqueous methanol or ethanol was used as an alternative of aqueous ML or EL for the reaction. In separate experiments, we confirmed by having the feed (aqueous ML or EL) stand for 24―72 h at room temperature that formation of LA from hydrolysis of ML or EL was not detectable. According to a recent study on catalytic dehydration of LA, there is a possibility that the reaction feed (aqueous solution of LA) may contain more or less LA dimers, whose amount would depend on the source of LA and storage time of the feed; when present in significant amount, the LA dimers in the feed can significantly shake the quantification of the catalytic results [54]. Such a possibility was excluded in this study based on the following experimental observations: 1) No LA dimer was detected in our analysis by GC and HPLC analyses of the feed solution and the reactor effluent condensates as well for the reaction of LA; 2) After having the feed and condensate solutions either stand for up to 7 days or diluted with water up to 500 times, no increment in the amount of LA was confirmed by conducting more sensitive IC analysis for accurate quantification of LA [23]; 3) The aqueous solution of LA was treated at 80 °C for durations of 16―20 h prior to its use as the reaction feed, using the method described in ref 54, but these pretreatments did not change the LA content in the feed and produced essentially no effect on the catalytic reaction data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 AA production from the lactic esters (ML and EL) Fig. 1 presents the performance of the HAP m -360 catalysts in the reaction of ML by showing the time course curves of ML conversion and AA selectivity. The ML conversion (Fig. 1A) decreased more or less with time-on-stream (TOS) in the early stage (TOS < 6 h) of the reaction but hereafter became stabilized. The HAP m -360 catalysts offered fairly stable selectivity for the formation of the desirable product AA (Fig. 1B). The data also disclose that the catalyst with lower m always produced a higher ML conversion and thus showed a higher activity, which are similar to the LTA reaction over the same catalyst samples [23]. The AA selectivity increased from ca. 52 % at m = 1.58 to ca. 58 % at m = 1.60 but decreased to 36 % when m was further increased up to m = 1.68, indicating that there exits an optimal catalyst composition (i.e., m = 1.60) for offering the highest AA selectivity. Note that this optimal composition m = 1.60 for AA production from ML differs slightly from that identified in our earlier study of AA production from LA, which was m = 1.62 [23]. Table 1 details the stabilized ML conversion and product selectivity over the HAP m -360 catalysts, which were obtained during the period of TOS = 7∼8 h. In consistent with the data reported earlier for the same reaction over other catalysts [24–31], AA always appeared as the major product (36–58 %) and AD the most abundant byproduct (13∼19 %); other byproducts with selectivity no smaller than 1% were methyl acrylate (MA: ca. 2%) and propionic acid (PA: ca. 1%). Apparently, the stabilized selectivity for AD was steadily lowered, from 19 % to 13 %, when m in the HAP m -360 catalyst was increased from m = 1.58 up to m = 1.68 though the variation of m had little impact on the selectivity for PA. It should be mentioned that the selectivity for MA (ca. 2%) was surprisingly low if one would refer the overall reaction as a “dehydration” process of ML; this low MA selectivity strongly contrasts to the high AA selectivity as the measured AA-to-MA ratio (AA/MA) in the products was no smaller than 18, which would have important implication to the reaction mechanism of ML. Except the clearly named products in the table, any other minor products with an individual selectivity of less than 1%, including 2,3-pentanedione (2,3-PD: < 0.1 %) and carbonaceous surface deposit as well, were summed up and shown as “Others” in the table. The overall selectivity for the “Others” decreased from 26 % at m = 1.58 to ca. 21 % at m = 1.60 but became almost doubled (38 %) at m = 1.62 and then more than doubled (48 %) at m = 1.68. Note that the highest overall selectivity for the “Others” was obtained over the catalyst HAP1.68-360 (m = 1.68) showing the lowest selectivity for AA production. The reacted catalysts were subjected to temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) measurements in the TG/DTG mode [55] to quantify the carbonaceous deposits accumulated on the catalyst surface during the reaction up to 8 h (Fig. 1). The quantities are given in the last column of Table 1. It is seen that the carbonaceous deposits increased by 40 % on increasing m of the catalyst, from 0.45 mg⋅ m−2-cat over the catalyst of m = 1.58 (HAP1.58-360) to 0.62 mg⋅ m−2-cat over the one of m = 1.68 (HAP1.68-360). Obviously, HAP1.60-360 (m = 1.60) appeared as the best catalyst for AA production as it offered the highest selectivity and yield for AA production. Fig. 2 shows the performance of the HAP m -360 catalysts for AA production in the reaction of EL. The time course curves of EL conversion and AA selectivity appear qualitatively similar to those presented in Fig. 1 for the reaction of ML though in the early stage of the reaction the EL conversion (Fig. 2A) decreased relative faster than did the ML conversion in Fig. 1A; the catalyst with lower m always offered again a higher EL conversion and thus a higher activity, and the HAP1.60-360 sample was again identified to be the most selective catalyst for AA production from EL. For quantitative comparison, the reactant conversion levels were always a little lower but the AA selectivity a little higher in the reaction of EL (Fig. 2) than those in the reaction of ML (Fig. 1), regardless of the catalyst. These data demonstrate that the EL is less active but more selective than ML for the production of AA. Shown in Table 2 are the stabilized EL conversion and product selectivity data measured during the period of TOS = 7∼8 h. The EL conversion decreased with the increase of m, from 55 % at m = 1.58 to ca. 33 % at m = 1.68. And, the selectivity and yield for AA were maximized at 60 % over the catalyst of m = 1.60. Compared to the results of the ML reaction, the conversion level of EL decreased by ca. 12 %; the selectivity data for the desired AA and EA were enhanced by 3–5 % and 50 %, respectively, but the selectivity for AD and the “Others” lowered by 10 % and 5%, respectively, though change in the selectivity for PA was not detectable. The amounts of carbonaceous deposits on each of the HAP m -360 catalysts are presented in the last column of Table 2, showing that the carbonaceous deposits increased by 38 % on increasing m of the catalyst, from 0.40 mg⋅ m−2-cat over HAP1.58-360 (m = 1.58) to 0.55 mg⋅ m−2-cat over HAP1.68-360 (m = 1.68). However, it is of interest to note that the carbonaceous deposits accumulated on every catalyst during the reaction of EL were significant less than those during the reaction of ML even though the loss of catalyst activity in the early stage of the reaction (TOS < 6 h) was more severe in the reaction of EL. It is inferred that the higher selectivity for producing AA and EA would have helped to reduce formation of the carbonaceous deposits. More discussion on this point will be made in the next section. Fig. 3 presents a detailed comparison of the product distribution for the reactions of ML and EL at varying conversion levels over the HAP1.60-360 catalyst; the conversion levels were measured by varying the reaction feed space velocity in the range of GHSV = 3280―16400 mL⋅g-cat−1⋅ h−1, as shown in Figures S1 and S2 of Supplementary material. Although the selectivity-conversion curves for the reactions of ML and EL appear very similar in Fig. 3 it is distinctive that the reaction of EL always produced a higher selectivity for the desirable AA and lower selectivity for the other products except EA, demonstrating the advantage of EL as the preferable feedstock for AA production. For the reaction of EL, the AA selectivity increased from 58 % to 62 % when the conversion of EL was elevated from 25 % to 39 % and then decreased to 55 % on further increasing the EL conversion up to 87 % (Fig. 3B). The low AA selectivity at the low EL conversion levels (or high feed GHSV) was clearly compensated by the formation of byproducts mainly in the “Others”. These trends resemble those of the LTA reaction over the HAP1.62−360 catalyst reported in our previous study [23]. However, the lowering of AA selectivity at higher EL conversion levels (or lower feed GHSV) appears to be compensated mainly by the formation of the major byproduct AD. Although the selectivity for EA was no higher than 4%, its continued increase with the EL conversion well supports the argument that EA was not a primary but secondary product, probably generated by esterification of the primary product AA with EtOH. 3.2 Reactivity of ML, EL and LA and their product selectivity The HAP1.60-360 catalyst, which showed the highest selectivity and yield for AA production from both ML and EL, was then employed to compare the reactivity of ML, EL and LA and their product selectivity. Our previous study on the reaction of LA (LTA reaction) over the HAP m -360 catalysts used a much higher feed space velocity (GHSV = 7016 mL⋅g-cat−1⋅ h−1 or WHSVLA = 2.1 h−1) due to high reactivity of LA [23]. The LTA reaction was carried out again in this study over the HAP1.60-360 catalyst under conditions exactly the same as those employed for studying the reactions of ML and EL in the preceding section, i.e., 360 °C, 3.9 kPa LA, 35.1 kPa H2O, 61 kPa N2, GHSV =4920 mL⋅g-cat−1⋅ h−1 (WHSVLA = 1.0 h−1), to make a rigorous comparison between the reactions of LA, ML and EL. Fig. 4 compares the time course curves of the reactant (LA, ML and EL) conversion and AA selectivity. The time courses of LA conversion and AA selectivity are at no surprising essentially similar to those of LTA reaction (under much higher space velocity) in the previous work [23]; as it would be anticipated by significantly lowering the feed space velocity, the LA conversion levels became significantly higher (92–95 %) but the AA selectivity lower (53 %) in this study. Also, the data in Fig. 4 clearly demonstrate that the ester reactants (ML and EL) were much less reactive than LA although among the two ester reactants ML was more reactive than EL. However, the most reactive LA produced the lowest AA selectivity (ca. 53 %) and the least reactive EL the highest AA selectivity (ca. 60 %). Similar orders of reactivity and selectivity for AA were also reported earlier over a composite Ca3(PO4)2–Ca2(P2O7) (50:50 wt%) catalyst by Han et al. [27], who compared the gas-phase reactions of aqueous LA, ML and EL (50 wt% in water) at 390 °C under very low feed space velocity (GHSV: ca. 600 mL⋅g-cat−1⋅ h−1 or WHSVreactant: ca. 0.26 h-1); the least reactive EL produced the highest (79 %) and the most active LA the lowest AA selectivity (54 %). Fig. 5 compares the time course curves for each of the clearly named byproducts and the “Others” as well during the reactions of LA, ML and EL, to gain information on the byproduct evolution (and thus change of product selectivity). The overall trends of the curves for the individual byproduct in the reactions of either ester were at no exception similar to those from the reaction of LA; AD and MA or EA (Fig. 5A) decreased but PA as well as the “Others” (Fig. 5B) increased with TOS in the early stage of the reactions (TOS < 6 h). Considering that the direct dehydration of either ML or EL should have produced acrylate ester (MA or EA) as their major products but in fact AA was still obtained as the major product in the reactions of either ML or EL; the molar AA-to-acrylate ester ratio (AA/MA or AA/EA) was as high as 13∼29 (Tables 1 and 2). It seems highly possible that the ester reactant would lose their alkyl group by hydrolysis to LA (or adsorbed lactate) at the catalyst surface and the latter was then serving as the key intermediate to the production of AA. Detailed discussion on the mechanism of LTA reaction over HAP and zeolite catalysts was presented in our previous studies [10,12,23]. The much lower reactivity of the ester reactants than that of LA (Fig. 4) would indicate that the preceding hydrolysis reaction was much slower compared to the later dehydration reaction of the intermediate LA (or surface lactate), which explains why the formation of LA was not observable during the reactions of both esters; the initial catalytic rate for LA consumption (1.5 μmol min−1 m−2) measured under kinetically relevant conditions was 3∼4 times higher than that for ML (0.42 μmol min−1 m−2) and EL consumptions (0.38 μmol min−1 m−2). As the catalyst surface acidity was shown to be responsible for the formation of AD from LA [6,7,10–13,17–23,38–40], the similarity between the time courses for the conversion of the two ester reactants (Fig. 4A) and AD selectivity (Fig. 5A) would imply that the catalyst surface acidity was responsible for catalyzing hydrolysis of the ester reactants. In separate experiments, 2 wt% ML and EL in water were reacted over the HAP1.60-360 catalyst at 120 °C in a batch reactor to compare the hydrolysis reactivity of the esters; the rates were 0.36 and 0.26 μmol⋅ min−1⋅ m-2 for the consumption of ML and EL, respectively. The time course for the formation of either MA or EA during the reaction of ML or EL (Fig. 5 A) also appeared similar to that for AD formation from LA, which would hint an association of the catalyst surface acidity with the formation of either MA or EA by esterification of AA with either methanol or ethanol during the reactions of ML or EL. These explanations seem to be supported by the observations of Xu et al. [31] on the reaction of ML over sodium exchanged Y zeolite catalyst: the apparent activation energy for a direct MA production was 50 − 65 kJ/mol higher than that for AA production and the preferable route for MA formation would be the esterification of AA with methanol. The minor byproduct PA (Fig. 5B) would be produced by hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis of LA and AA [10–12,20,23]; the hydrogen required for this reaction could be supplied by those undesirable reactions producing the “Others”, as could be inferred from the paralleled formation of PA with the “Others” (Fig. 5B). Scheme 1 summarizes the above discussion by proposing the possible reaction channels leading to the detected products. To gain further support to these proposals, the effect of water partial pressure (PH2O) on the reaction of EL was studied over the HAP1.60-360 catalyst (Fig. 6 and Table S1). Increasing P H2O from 15.2 kPa to 35.1 kPa clearly enhanced the conversion level of EL (Fig. 6A) and the selectivity for AA (Fig. 6B) and AD (Fig. 6C) but lowered the selectivity for the “Others” (Fig. 6D) and improved the catalyst stability. The enhancement in EL conversion could be easily understood as the increase in P H2O would “make” the system in favor of EL hydrolysis while the enhanced selectivity for AA would be due to that more water molecules would inhibit formation of those byproducts in the “Others”. However, the selectivity for AA was slightly lowered when P H2O was further increased from 35.1–74.4 kPa, suggesting that there exits an optimal P H2O (i.e., P H2O = 35.1 kPa) for offering the highest AA selectivity. However, the selectivity for AD kept on increasing with P H2O, which could arise from the effect of water on the surface acidity; higher P H2O could induce generation of more Brønsted acid sites by hydrolysis of the phosphate at the catalyst surface, probably at the expense of Lewis acid and base sites [56]. As Brønsted acidic sites appear to be responsible for catalyzing the formation of AD from LA [12,39,40] as well as ML [14], it is not surprising that the selectivity for AD increased steadily with P H2O. We also measured the apparent activation energies for the reactions of LA and EL over the HAP1.62-360 catalyst, which are 91 and 114 kJ/mol, respectively. Ethanol (EtOH) was used to replace H2O (co-feed) for the reaction of EL over the HAP1.60-360 catalyst the results are shown in Table S2. It is confirmed in separate experiment that EtOH alone was not reactive over the same catalyst. The replacement by EtOH of water in the feed significantly lowered both the conversion of EL and selectivity for AA but the selectivity for EA (ethyl acrylate) was enhanced by ten-fold, indicating that the presence of a large amount of EtOH (molar EtOH/EL = 9) reduced the reactivity of EL and promoted the formation of EA. The selectivity for the “Others” byproducts also increased significantly. Note that the combined selectivity for AA and EA during the reaction in EtOH was still significantly lower than the AA selectivity under H2O presence. On the other hand, EtOH replacement of H2O produced little effect on the overall reactivity of LA but significantly lowered the selectivity for AA production (Table S3). The reaction of LA in EtOH (molar EtOH/LA = 9) also produced considerable amounts of EL and EA, indicating that the esterification reactions of EtOH with LA and AA were also prevalent. Contrasting to the reaction of EL (Table S2), the reaction of LA in EtOH significantly lowered the selectivity for the “Others” byproducts, probably due to that the esterification reactions significantly reduced the effective concentration of LA and AA for side reactions leading to the “Others”. Note that the combined selectivity for AA and EA during the reaction of LA in EtOH was comparable to the AA selectivity measured during the reaction in H2O (Table S3), which again well supports that EA was produced from the secondary esterification reaction of AA with EtOH. The above observations on the effects of P H2O and EtOH replacement of H2O on the reaction of EL (Fig. 6 and Table S2) therefore well support our proposition that the ester reactants (ML and EL) were first converted by a slow acid-catalyzed hydrolysis chemistry into LA or adsorbed lactate as the surface intermediate, followed by a faster transformation of the intermediate to produce the desirable AA. 3.3 Correlation between the performance and surface acid − base property of the HAP m -360 catalysts for AA production from LA, ML and EL It has been shown that a cooperative acid-base bifunctional catalysis mechanism was prevailing for the LTA reaction over HAP [21–23] and other solid catalysts [6,10–13,18,22,23] and a suitable balance between the catalyst surface acidity and basicity would be the key for improving the AA selectivity and yield [6,10–13,18,20,23]. The surface acid-base property for the serial HAP m -360 catalysts were measured, respectively, by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD) at above 100 °C [23]. The acid strength of the acidic sites changed little but the number of the surface acidic sites (i.e., acidity) became reduced on increasing m (Ca/P ratio); however, the base strength of the basic sites became slightly strengthened but the number of the surface basic sites significantly increased with the increment of m [23]. The overall base strength was thus higher and the acidity/basicity ratio lower on the sample with a higher m; e.g., the measured acidity/basicity ratio was lowered from 7.0 at m = 1.58 to ca. 1.8 at to 1.8 at m = 1.68, as shown in Figure S3 [23]. An attempt is then made in Fig. 7 to correlate the product selectivity with the surface acid-base property of the HAP m -360 catalysts for the reactions of ML and EL, respectively. As it was documented earlier from this [10–12,23] and other laboratories [6,7,17–22,38–40] in the studies of the LTA reaction, the selectivity for AD increased steadily with increasing the acidity/basicity ratio at the catalyst surface (Fig. 7), implying that the catalyst surface acidity was responsible for the formation of AD by promoting the decarboxylation/decarbonylation of the intermediate LA or adsorbed lactate species during the reactions of both ML (Fig. 7A) and EL (Fig. 7B). The data in Fig. 7 also show that there was an optimum acidity/basicity ratio (ca. 4.5) at the catalyst surface for maximizing the selectivity for AA and minimizing the overall selectivity for the “Others” in the reactions of both esters. The contrasting dependences of AA and the “Others” on the catalyst surface acidity/basicity ratio disclose that the improved AA selectivity over the different catalysts was due to avoidance or prevention of the formation of a number of minor (< 1 % by carbon balance) byproducts, whose exact nature remains to be identified. Similar results were also documented in the earlier studies on the LTA reaction over the HAP m -360 [23] and other solid acid-base catalysts [5,10–12,16,18], which again argue for that LA or its associated surface adsorbed lactate species was generated as the key intermediate on the catalyst surface during the conversion towards AA production of both ML and EL. These results therefore indicate that both surface acidic and basic sites are essential for the formation of AA from the ester reactants, and a properly balanced surface acidity and basicity is crucial for maximizing the AA production rate [10–12,23]. It deserves, however, to note that the optimum acidity/basicity ratio (ca. 4.5) for obtaining the maximum AA selectivity in the reactions of both esters in Fig. 7 is significantly higher than the ratio (ca. 3.2) for maximizing the AA selectivity in the LTA reaction over these HAP m -360 catalysts [23]. This difference can be explained on the basis of the preceding discussion: the ester reactant (ML or EL) had to be first hydrolyzed at the acidic sites on the catalyst surface to generate the LA or adsorbed lactate species as the surface intermediate, from which the desirable product AA would then be obtained through catalytic dehydration by cooperation of the surface acidic (Ca2+) and basic (phosphate oxygen) sites, as depicted in Scheme 2 . As the rate of LA consumption by dehydration was always much faster than the rate of its formation from the hydrolysis of either ML or EL, a higher acidity (or acidity/basicity ratio) should therefore be required for the production of AA from both ML and EL than from LA. This again points to that the hydrolysis reaction of the ester reactant determined the overall kinetics of the ML-to-AA and EL-to-AA processes. 4 Conclusions This work presents the first comparative study of the reactions of aqueous ML, EL and LA for the production of AA over the hydroxyapatite catalysts of varying Ca/P ratios (HAP m -360, 1.58 ≤ m ≤ 1.68). The ester reactants (ML and EL) showed much lower reactivity but offered much higher selectivity than LA for the production of AA; of the two esters, ML was more reactive but presented a lower selectivity for AA production. The facts that AA, which cannot be produced by direct dehydration of either ML or EL, was the prevailing product during the reactions of ML and EL and that the product distribution of these reactions appeared very similar to that of the LTA reaction, demonstrate that the ester reactants were transformed at the catalyst surface by acid-catalyzed hydrolysis to LA or adsorbed lactate, which then served as the key surface intermediate leading to AA production. This conclusion was corroborated by the effects of water partial pressure and ethanol replacement of water on the reaction of EL, as well as the observation that ML showed a higher reactivity than EL for the hydrolysis reaction over the best performing HAP1.60-360. These catalytic tandem processes for the ML-to-AA and EL-to-AA reactions were backed by correlating the product selectivity with the catalyst surface acid-base property. The optimum acidity/basicity ratio for producing the highest AA selectivity was the same in the reactions of both ML and EL but significantly higher than the ratio in the reaction of LA, which points to an operation of acid-base bifunctional catalysis in enabling the ML-to-AA and EL-to-AA reactions. coredata.dc:description: Gas-phase “dehydration” of methyl (ML) and ethyl lactates (EL) for acrylic acid (AA) production was studied and compared with the dehydration of lactic acid (LA) over serial hydroxyapatite catalysts of varying compositions (HAP m -360, molar Ca/P ratio m = 1.58–1.68, calcination temperature: 360 °C). The product distribution from both lactic esters was found very similar to that from LA; AA but not methyl (MA) or ethyl acrylate (EA) also appeared as the prevailing product (> 50 mol% by selectivity) from both ML and EL. Compared with the reaction of LA, both esters showed much lower reactivity but higher AA selectivity. Among the two esters EL was less reactive but produced a higher selectivity for AA formation. Correlating the AA selectivity or yield with the catalyst surface acid-base property uncovers that a suitable balance between the surface acidity and basicity (or acidity/basicity ratio) is the key to the lactic ester-to-AA reactions. However, the optimum surface acidity/basicity ratio for producing the highest AA selectivity from both esters was higher than that from LA. These results suggest that the lactic ester-to-AA reactions proceeded by catalytic tandem processes involving a formation of LA (or adsorbed lactate) as the key intermediate at the catalyst surface. Acid-base catalysis responsible for these observations is discussed.
coredata.dc:title: Comparative study of gas-phase “dehydration” of alkyl lactates and lactic acid for acrylic acid production over hydroxyapatite catalysts
